utterances: Well I think of you...
And right wing demagoguery.

And this left wing goofy guy used to hanging around Berkeley.
I knew, finally, you'd hit the ancient - the Mecca.
You know, Berkeley: I knew you'd get there, Reich.
This is where mainstream America lives, Alan.
You have to just get in touch with average Americans here.
To think that Harvard didn't have you far enough left, now you went over, clear over there.
And that was that you and I were on opposite sides of almost every issue.
Not only do we not see eye to eye, but you are very tall, in fact, obscenely tall.
You're six foot what?
Seven.
So you're...
And you...
You're 6'7"" and I'm...
And you're...
I'm 4'10"" and a half...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
...so not only do we not see eye to eye on political issues, but we rarely have seen eye to eye ever.
Remember when Galbraith would come to class and you were there and John Kenneth got up and he said, Simpson and I don't see eye to eye on anything until we stand up, because he was six, eight.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Yes.
That's right.
You two used to do a TV show called The Long and Short of It.
Oh.
It was a very popular...
I don't know where they came up with that name.
It's funny.
Yeah, you know, there's, it's always a stretch for some.
Anyway, let's get some more listeners on the line.
This is Mike, Mike calling us from Angola, Indiana.
Good afternoon.
Afternoon, Mike.
Go ahead.
Fun to hear this.
I was just relating a story about Bob Dole.

When I was a student journalist at Drake University in De Moines, Iowa, we had the opportunity of covering the - a Lincoln - statewide Lincoln day event - and all of the presidential contenders were there for the Republican Party, with the exception of Ronald Reagan.
And Bob Dole was hilarious.
When he was able to get up on stage and talk, he - I believe he followed George Bush and... H.W.
And prior to Mr. Bush, there was a large release of balloons and what not.
And when Dole took the stage, some of the balloons hit the lights and started popping.
And he looked up and he said, I think somebody's bubble has just burst.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
And went on with a number of one-liners before he got into the policy statements that all the hardcore Republicans were there to hear.
So Bob Dole, another example of being funny.
Thanks very much, Mike, for that.
You're welcome.
And...
You know who I think also has a great sense of humor.
I don't know if you've already talked about him on this program, and that is Al Gore.
He is not known in public to have a great sense of humor.
In fact, the joke that he plays on himself very often is that he's kind of wooden.
But one on one, or in a small group, he is one of the funniest people I know.
And I managed to communicate that so brilliantly on the campaign trail.
Yeah.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Now Reich, I have never heard you say that in all of our intimate dealings, that Al Gore had that kind of humor.
Now you - what you - you are on the vapors.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
I thought I would - I thought I'd save it just in case.
Well you did.
I mean I just fell off on the floor here.
I never saw that.
He is not very much.
I think he's very good, very, very funny fellow.
Well he didn't...
And...
Well, he didn't think it was funny when you bagged Bradley over him in the primary.
That's true, he didn't laugh about that.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
But anyway...
We have subsequently, shared a joke about that.
I see.
Well I don't want to get into your internal struggles within your own party.
But it's also self-deprecating humor, and I think this is something you've talked about.
I never saw that in Al.
If I had, I would've had - I had trouble with him.
I didn't legislate with him.
I couldn't figure him out sometimes.
There were certain things I never have tracked, but if you say that, I - that's a helpful salve for me.
